ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

AEDES MOSQUITO PROBLEM
(Measures to tackle)


    1. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for the Environment if he will enlighten the House on the magnitude of the Aedes mosquito problem in Singapore and how his Ministry is tackling the problem.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Aedes mosquito problem is still serious. In 1991, there were 2,178 reported cases of dengue fever or dengue haemorrhagic fever and six deaths. In the first eight months of this year, there were 1,964 cases and one death. For the same period last year, there were 1,417 cases.

Column: 177



    Mosquito breeding within premises is still prevalent. In the first eight months of this year, my officers carried out some 440,000 inspections and found 4,919 instances of breeding. In other words, there were 12 instances of breeding for every 1,000 inspections. Last year, Sir, some 990,000 inspections were carried out and there were 7,273 instances of breeding. This works out to 7 instances for every 1,000 inspections.

    My Ministry will continue to educate the public on the danger of the Aedes mosquito. Vector control operations have also been stepped up. Every day, some 200 Public Health Inspectors are deployed for this purpose. More stringent enforcement action was introduced this year.

    In the first eight months of this year, 2,268 households with mosquito breeding within their premises were fined. Two repeat offenders were charged in court. Another 1,066 non-residential premises found to be breeding mosquitoes were also dealt with in court.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Sir, would the Minister say that the problem is now well under control?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: I would like to say that, but at the moment I think it is still serious. Therefore, we need to get the cooperation of everyone.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Cheng San GRC): Sir, apart from the Aedes mosquito and dengue fever, is there also an increase in the number of cases of malaria? If this is so, could the Minister inform the House what preventive steps are being taken to curtail the spread of malaria?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, malaria is not a problem in Singapore today. Through effective vector control measures by the Ministry of the Environment, we are able to keep the population of Anopheles mosquito, which transmits the disease, very low. Because of this, Singapore was declared malaria-free by WHO in 1982.

    All cases of malaria reported in recent years were imported cases. In other words, the victims contracted the disease

Column: 178

outside Singapore. My Ministry will continue to be vigilant against the re-introduction of malaria in Singapore.

    For the information of this House, Sir, for some years now, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore have been having biennial meetings to discuss and exchange information on malaria. From 1990 onwards, these biennial meetings have been subsumed under the Brunei-Indonesia-Malaysia-Singapore (BIMS) Border Health Conference. And for the information of Mr Das, the next BIMS Border Health Conference will be hosted in Singapore in November this year.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): May I ask the Minister two supplementary questions? (1) What is the level of public awareness of the danger of Aedes mosquito? (2) Since swing-fogging is an effective method of killing mosquitoes, why is it not frequently used to wipe out Aedes mosquitoes?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, extensive publicity on dengue fever and Aedes mosquito through the print and TV media as well as educational materials that have been widely distributed to members of the public, have indeed heightened awareness amongst the general public. And this was confirmed by results of a survey conducted recently by my Ministry. But, nonetheless, Sir, my Ministry will make special efforts to reach out to as many people as possible, including foreign maids, foreign workers, school principals, grassroots leaders, estate managers, etc. I would like to emphasize, Sir, in order to bring the disease under control we need the support of everyone.

    Mr Chin is quite right in saying that swing-fogging is currently the most effective method of killing adult mosquitoes. But unless we can literally wipe out all the adult mosquitoes, those that escape will continue to breed if breeding grounds are made available. Then we are back to square one.

    Therefore, in our vector control operations, emphasis is on the permanent elimination of breeding habitats. If we can deny the mosquitoes a chance to breed and multiply, we can

Column: 179

keep the mosquito population so low that it no longer poses a threat. That is what we have done in our efforts to control malaria. We are able to keep the Anopheles mosquito population so low that malaria is no longer a problem, as I have said earlier on in my answer to Mr Chandra Das.

    However, in the case of the Aedes mosquito, Sir, my Ministry finds the task a bit harder because this species of mosquito breeds mainly in homes and we cannot be present in people's homes all the time to check and make sure that there are no breedings. That is why, in order to bring the disease under control, I must emphasize, once again, that we need the support of everyone.

Column: 179

COOKED FOOD AND MARKET-PRODUCE STALLS
(Vacancies)


    2. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for the Environment how many cooked food and market-produce stalls under the management of the Housing and Development Board and his Ministry are still vacant and whether these stalls will be re-opened for application.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, currently, markets and food centres that will not be affected by redevelopment have 2,100 vacant stalls, and of these, 327 are cooked food stalls and the remaining 1,773 are market-produce stalls. All vacant cooked food stalls are being reserved for stallholders affected by redevelopment. This is because the number of stallholders to be relocated is more than the vacancies.

    For the market-produce stalls, the Ministry of the Environment is examining how best these vacancies can be taken up. Once finalised, details will be made known.

REAR SEAT BELT REQUIREMENTS
(Grace period)


    3. Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in respect of

Column: 180

the rear seat belt requirements to take effect from 1st October 1992, whether the Traffic Police will consider giving motorists a grace period during which the Traffic Police can conduct a campaign to educate and advise motorists on the need for rear seat belts.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the regulation on the use of child restraints in the front seat came into effect on 1st July this year, Traffic Police were aware that this new requirement needed explanation. It was necessary for motorists to know that the rule was in the interests of the safety of their children. Therefore, the Traffic Police gave a grace period during which the offenders were not booked but instead given written advisory notices and cautioned that they would be booked if they were caught again. As a result of this, there has been a high level of compliance with the front seat belt rules.

    Dr Arthur Beng as well as Dr Ow Chin Hock, Chairman of the Feedback Unit, have both informed me that the requirement of seat belts for rear seats is more complicated and therefore requires further public education so as to avoid confusion and misunderstanding. For example, some people still have the misperception that the rear seats are safer than the front seats and that therefore there is no real need for this requirement.

    Traffic Police will next week launch a comprehensive public education programme on the need to use seat belts and child restraints in the rear seats. It will be a major education programme, with television commercials, advertisements in the press, posters and leaflets.

    As was done for the front seat requirements, Traffic Police will also give a grace period for the rear belt rules. During this period, which will be for three months, Traffic Police will exercise flexibility on first time offenders, who will be cautioned and advised of the need to belt up.

APPLICATIONS FOR PERMANENT
RESIDENCE
(By male and female spouses of
Singapore citizens)


    4. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will state the number of applications by male and female spouses of Singapore citizens for permanent residence in 1991; what was the success rate; and if his Ministry is willing to allow the economic and financial status of the Singaporean spouse to be the determining factor in such applications, regardless of sex.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1991, 4,676 female spouses of Singapore citizens applied for permanent residence (PR). The approval rate was 68%. In the same year, 1,284 male spouses of Singapore citizens applied for permanent residence. The approval rate was 57%.

    As for the second part of the Member's question, Immigration Department does take into account the qualifications and skills of the Singaporean spouse in assessing such PR applications, regardless of whether the spouse is the husband or wife. The only distinction is that where the foreign spouse is the husband he should be gainfully employed and has the means to look after his family.

INVESTMENT IN MOUNT CHARLOTTE GROUP


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Finance if he will say how much was invested in the Mount Charlotte group and whether the investment has suffered any loss and, if so, what is the extent of the loss so far.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, to date the total investment in the Mount Charlotte Group is S$821 million or £274 million.

    No shares in Mount Charlotte have been sold so that there has been no realised loss. Mount Charlotte is a public limited company but its shares are not currently listed in the London Stock Exchange (LSE). The shares were

Column: 182

previously listed in the LSE, but trading in the shares was stopped when the Brierley Group acquired 100% of Mount Charlotte's equity in December 1990. Shareholders' intention is for the company to be refloated at an opportune time in the future in a few years' time and to have its shares relisted on the LSE.

    Shares in Mount Charlotte were purchased as a long term investment. Therefore, the return from this investment can be determined when Mount Charlotte is relisted on the LSE.

    1991 was the most difficult year for UK hotels in 30 years as the tourist industry was badly affected by the Gulf War and the UK recession. Even in 1991, Mount Charlotte operated profitably, increased its average room rate in the key London market and continued to achieve the highest returns on turnover in the industry.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, it was reported that the hotel occupancy rate had been at its worst since 1980. Why then did the Government decide to buy 30% of Mount Charlotte for around £237.5 million in May 1991?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: There was a proposal by Mount Charlotte to restructure its debt structure to eliminate a large amount of short-term debts at relatively high interest rates through the issuance of convertible bonds and it was the purchase of these bonds which accounts for this 1991 purchase.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Under what consideration did the Government decide to pump in another £150 million to save the hotel, as it was reported?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: It is a statement which is totally untrue. It is not to save the company. As I mentioned earlier, it was to restructure the debt, to lower the interest burden.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Would the Minister estimate how much Singapore could recover from the investment should the hotel be eventually wound up?

Column: 183



     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: It would not be wound up. The hotel will be profitable in a few years' time. I cannot predict what is going to happen in a few years' time. But, hopefully, with the recovery of the hotel market in London, which is incidentally the largest single hotel market in the world, and will remain so even when UK is part of the European Community, it will remain for a long, long time as a major tourist hotel market in Europe.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Can I take it that the Minister is confident that the investment on the hotel would give us a good return by 1995 or 1996?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I cannot predict 1995 or 1996, but the investment would not have been made if we did not have any assumption that it would be profitable in the longer term. But I cannot commit myself to specific dates, just as I think the Member would find it difficult to predict what is going to happen in the world in 1995.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Minister agree that if the money is invested somewhere else, or in other investment instruments, the investment would have a better yield?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: There is no such assurance. We could have lost it either or made more money. I cannot predict such suppositions.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Minister agree that the level of risk tolerance for Government investment is much lower than private capital investment, as the Government's money is the people's money?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: That is true. This is what we do for the bulk of our investments, including Mount Charlotte. It could be argued that in the short-term it does not look as good as it ought to be. But again, all investments are of that nature, unless you are prepared to put it in the bank, and earn a couple of percent interest.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Has the financial position of Mount Charlotte improved since it was reported the last time?

Column: 184



     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Indeed, it has.

TECHNOLOGIES HOLDINGS GROUP
(Investment in Silicon Valley)


    6. Mr Ling How Doong asked the Minister for Finance if he will say what was the total amount of investment by Singapore through Technologies Holdings Group in the Silicon Valley in Australia; whether the investment suffered any loss in 1991 and 1992; and what was the extent of the loss.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, the hon. Member refers to the "Silicon Valley in Australia". I am not aware of such a place. I am assuming he means the Silicon Valley of California, USA.

    Singapore Technologies Ventures (STV) is one of the five sector companies in Singapore Technologies Holdings (STH) and has invested a total of S$38 million in Silicon Valley companies. Net loss from those investments in 1991 amounted to S$5 million. Net loss in 1992 is expected to be less than S$0.5 million.

    Investment in venture companies should be seen in a wider context and over a longer time frame. Not all investments will be profitable, nor always on a year by year basis. For example, total STV venture capital investments in the United States as well as other parts of the world are S$80 million at cost. For these investments, including those in Silicon Valley, while net loss in 1991 was S$7 million, for the period January to August 1992, there is a net realised gain of S$16 million. Additional net unrealised gain to date is more than S$50 million.

    Another STH sector company, Chartered Industries of Singapore (CIS) has invested S$280,000 in one company in Silicon Valley. This company has got into financial difficulties. CIS will be writing off this investment in its 1992 accounts.

    The remaining three sector companies of STH have no investments in the Silicon Valley.

HDB RENTAL FLATS
(Number of applications)


    7. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether applications for Housing and Development Board rental flats increased in the years 1989 to 1991 and what steps are being taken to meet the housing need of the applicants.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang)(for the Minister for National Development): Sir, I am answering on behalf of the Minister for National Development.

    The total number of applications for HDB rental flats increased from 2,400 in 1989 to about 5,900 in 1991. This increase in demand for rental flats is largely due to a lowering of the minimum age limit for rental applicants. In 1989, the age limit for rental applicants who apply with a proper family nucleus was lowered from 29 years to 21 years of age. In 1990, the age limit for rental of HDB flats by single persons under the Joint Singles Scheme was also revised to 35 years for both male and female applicants. Prior to the revision, the age limit was set at 40 years for males and 35 years for female applicants.

    At present, there are about 4,900 applicants on the waiting list for HDB rental flats. About 1,400 flats are currently available for rental to citizen families. To meet the rise in demand for rental flats, HDB has increased the supply of rental flats. An additional 2,300 flats will be released for rental in the coming months. This will significantly reduce the waiting list for rental flats.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Will the Ministry review the 20% downpayment requirement for new purchase flats so that the problems faced by rental applicants in applying for such flats will be reduced to some extent?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The tenancies of rental applicants do not suggest that people are going into rental flats because they cannot afford to purchase flats. That

Column: 186

is not the main reason for the increase in number of applications. In any case, the 20% downpayment for purchase flats is not a new requirement. The 20% downpayment has always been a requirement, even under the old waiting list system. So the reason for the increase in number of applications for rental flats is not that people cannot afford to buy flats.

Column: 186

HDB RENTAL FLATS
(Numbers and types)


    8. Mr Cheo Chai Chen asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will state the numbers and types of Housing and Development Board flats (i) on rental to Singaporeans and (ii) vacant and presently available for rental to eligible Singaporeans and (b) whether steps have been taken to shorten the waiting time for eligible Singaporeans in urgent need of such flats.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang (for the Minister for National Development): At present, a total of 52,280 flats are let out at subsidised rents to lower income Singapore citizen families under the Public Scheme for Rental Flats.     I now deal first with that part of the Bill that is concerned with the electronic transfer of securities listed on the SES.

    Company law had for long required that every transfer of shares should be evidenced by a share certificate and the delivery of a completed transfer form to the company so that it could enter the name of the transferee in the company register and transfer the legal title to the shares to the transferee. Besides the great deal of paperwork involved, there is considerable delay between the time shares are sent for registration in the buyer's name and the time the shares are returned to the buyer. In the meantime, until he receives the physical share certificates from the company register, the buyer is denied the opportunity of re-selling the shares in the market at the opportune time.

    To overcome these problems, the Central Depository System was introduced. Transfer of listed securities by reproduction of share certificates and transfer forms under the paper-based settlement system will be replaced by book-entries in the computer-based records controlled by an operator called the Central Depository Pte Ltd, or simply known as the Depository. Such a major conversion exercise, involving hundreds of listed companies and thousands of shareholders, obviously cannot be accomplished overnight. Until this exercise is completed, the paper-based system of transfer for listed securities will continue to function in parallel with the book-entry settlement system on the stock exchange.

    As far as the trading in shares on the stock exchange by investors is concerned, this will continue in much the same way as under the paper-based system. Shares will still be bought and sold through brokers. Investors whose
